title: Animal Slander! Debunking 'Birdbrained' And 'Eat Like A Bird'
description:
Welcome back to "Animal Slander," the series where we take common expressions about animals and debunk them with science. Today on the show, we tackle "birdbrained" and to "eat like a bird" with biologists Corina Newsome and Alejandro Rico-Guevara.

Follow Maddie and Emily on Twitter. Their usernames are @maddie_sofia and @emilykwong1234. Plus, send us your animal slander—and questions and praise—by emailing the show at shortwave@npr.org.
copyright: Copyright 2019-2021 NPR - For Personal Use Only
itunes:title: Animal Slander! Debunking 'Birdbrained' And 'Eat Like A Bird'
itunes:author: NPR
itunes:summary: Is it accurate to say "eat like a bird?" Is "birdbrained" justified? NPR's Short Wave investigates the scientific validity of these common phrases.
itunes:subtitle: Is it accurate to say "eat like a bird?" Is "birdbrained" justified? NPR's Short Wave investigates the scientific validity of these common phrases.
content:encoded:
Welcome back to "Animal Slander," the series where we take common expressions about animals and debunk them with science. Today on the show, we tackle "birdbrained" and to "eat like a bird" with biologists Corina Newsome and Alejandro Rico-Guevara.
